Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides funding to help defray the expenses of participants in the West Coast Operator Algebra Seminar that will be held on October 5 and 6, 2018, on the campus of Seattle University. Additional information about this meeting can be found at the website: http://fac-staff.seattleu.edu/boersema/web/WCOAS/WCOAS2018.html.

This conference is the twenty-fifth installment of the West Coast Operator Algebra Seminar (WCOAS), a series that annually brings together a diverse group of mathematicians whose primary research interests are in the theory of operator algebras. These meetings cover many current aspects of research in the theory of C*-algebras and von Neumann algebras. Some of the 2018 emphasis will be on the following topics: subfactors and their invariants, rigidity for ergodic actions and von Neumann algebras, free probability and its applications, classification of C*-algebras (the Elliot program), noncommutative geometry, operator spaces, quantum groups, graph C*-algebras. The conference program broadens participation in the theory of operator algebras and provides ample opportunity for graduate students, postdocs, and other young scientists to present their work.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The West Coast Operator Algebra Seminar (WCOAS) was held at Seattle University on October 6-7, 2018.  There were 12 speakers at the seminar and 28 non-speaking participants. These participants consisted of graduate students, post-doctoral students, as well as established researchers in the operator algebras. It was a successful and stimulating seminar.


A scientific committee was formed in May 2018 to select the speakers who would be invited to give talks. This committee consisted of Adrian Ioana (University of California, San Diego),Zhuang Niu (University of Wyoming),Ian Putnam (University of Victoria),and Dimitri Shlyakhtenko (University of California, Los Angeles).


There were twelve 40-minute talks held on Saturday and on Sunday morning, October 6-7.  Speakers included established researchers as well as younger faculty members and post-docs. The committee was intentional about inviting a variety of speakers, including gender diversity and ethnic diversity.
The list of speakers and titles is below:

  • March Boedihardjo, University of California, Los Angeles,  ``Brown-Douglas-Fillmore theory for operators on l^p".
  • Robin Deeley, University of Colorado, ``Minimal dynamical systems and groupoids with prescribed K-theory".
  • Elizabeth Gillaspy, University of Montana, ``Generalized gauge actions, KMS states, and Hausdorff dimension for higher-rank graphs". 
  • David Jekel, University of California, Los Angeles, ``A New Proof of Analytic Subordination for Free Convolution, using Monotone Independence".
  • Todd Kemp, University of California, San Diego, ``Brown's Spectral Measure, and Free Brownian Motion".
  • Therese Landry, University of California, Riverside, ``Spectral Triples, Quantum Compact Metric Spaces, and the Sierpinski Gasket".
  • \item Brent Nelson, Vanderbilt University,  ``Non-tracial graph von Neumann algebras" .
  • Rolando de Santiago, University of California, Los Angeles, ``Tensor decompositions of II_1 factors arising from extensions of amalgamated free product groups".
  • Jorge Garza Vargas, University of California, Berkeley, ``Boolean extreme values".
  • Dan-Virgil Voiculescu, University of California, Berkeley, ``Commutants mod normed ideals and the modulus of quasicentral approximation".
  • Feng Xu, University of California, Riverside, ``Relative entropy in conformal field theory".
  • Ping Zhong, University of Wyoming, ``Some free probability aspects of meandric systems".


Two of the speakers and seven of the non-speaking participants were women. Five of the speakers and seven of the non-speaking participants identified as other than white.


For the seminar, about $13,851.16 was paid out of the NSF grant.  These funds were used entirely for reimbursement of travel and lodging expenses for the speakers and for some of the non-speaking participants, with priority given to students and junior faculty members. The NSF grant was used to support all twelve of the speakers and thirteen of the non-speaker participants. The West Coast Operator Algebra seminar also had support from PIMS (the Pacific Institute for the Mathematical Sciences) which was used for reimbursement of travel expenses for some of the participants who travelled from Canada.  

The 2018 WCOAS supported research in the field of operator algebras by (1) providing an opportunity for researchers to disseminate their results; (2) providing an opportunity for researchers, including graduate students and postdocs, to learnabout the recent research of others and to stay abreast of current work; (3) providing space and time for researchers to socialize and discuss their work together to foster collaboration and to strengthen the interaction of operator algebraists in this region.  There is a tradition of a strong research group of operator algebras along the west coast of North America, and the WCOAS is an important part of fostering that tradition.
